Chapter on Birth and Death (3-5)

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma - how does a bhiká¹£u gradually abandon the defilements, first abandoning unwholesome dharmas, next practicing wholesome dharmas, correctly contemplating and cultivating, the mind abiding in concentration?
He sees, hears, and knows, or sees with the divine eye:
That bhiká¹£u first observes in this way, the faculties and objects corresponding to each other, mutually causing each other, all worlds revolving in birth and death since beginningless time.
He observes in this way:
The causes and conditions of this birth, the great ocean of objects, are all without self. There is only the internal mind, the causes and conditions of objects, the transmigration of the world.

In this way, initially cultivating the practice of seclusion, leaving behind noisy places, delighting in empty and quiet places, in secluded places, in mountains, forests, among rice straw, under trees, in the open, or in charnel grounds, one is able to bind the monkey-like mind.

Through cultivation, the mind becomes tranquil, not delighting in villages, in places of singing, dancing, games, laughter, and commotion, not delighting in seeing women of all ages, not delighting in much speech.
There are two kinds of women that destroy pure conduct:
one is a prostitute, the other is one who speaks much, both of which are to be completely abandoned;
having abandoned them, the mind becomes single-pointedly tranquil, and the mind of that person is able to abide in this way.
What is right contemplation?
What dharmas are initially contemplated?
That person's initial mind contemplates the eighteen mental activities, which can give rise to wholesome roots, unwholesome roots, and indeterminate roots.
What are the eighteen?
It is said that the bhiká¹£u correctly contemplates the mind:
If one sees forms with the eyes and becomes attached with a joyful mind, one will receive unwholesome retribution;
If one arouses a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will obtain wholesome retribution;
If one arouses a mind of equanimity, one will obtain indeterminate retribution.
Moreover, in this way, if one hears sounds with the ears and becomes attached with a joyful mind, one will receive unwholesome retribution;
If one arouses a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will obtain wholesome retribution;
If one arouses a mind of equanimity, one will obtain indeterminate retribution.
Moreover, in this way, if one smells fragrances with the nose and becomes attached with a joyful mind, one will receive unwholesome retribution;
If one arouses a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will obtain wholesome retribution;
If one arouses a mind of equanimity, one will obtain indeterminate retribution.
Moreover, in this way, if one tastes flavors with the tongue and becomes attached with a joyful mind, one will receive unwholesome retribution;
If one arouses a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will obtain wholesome retribution;
If one arouses a mind of equanimity, one will obtain indeterminate retribution.
Moreover, if one's mind becomes attached to pleasant tactile sensations, one will receive unwholesome retributions;
if one gives rise to a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will receive wholesome retributions;
if one gives rise to a mind of equanimity, one will receive indeterminate retributions.
Moreover, if one's mind becomes attached to pleasant mental objects, one will receive unwholesome retributions;
if one gives rise to a sorrowful mind and a mind free from desire and attachment, one will receive wholesome retributions;
if one gives rise to a mind of equanimity, one will receive indeterminate retributions.
Due to these eighteen mental activities and the causes and conditions of the three retributions, beings are born and die in the world.

If a bhiká¹£u observes the eighteen mental activities in this way and attains the first stage, the earth spirits will see this and become even more joyful, passing on the news to the sky spirits in turn.ğŸ”½The earth spirits and the sky spirits, those two kinds of spirits, will joyfully tell the Four Heavenly Kings.
The Four Heavenly Kings will joyfully tell the Four Heavenly Kings, saying:

'In JambudvÄ«pa, in such and such a country, in such and such a village, in such and such a town, a good man of such and such a family and such and such a name, shaved his beard and hair, donned the Dharma robes, and went forth with right faith;
having gone forth, he left the noisy places and stayed in a quiet place, now contemplating the eighteen mental activities, and has realized that Dharma.'
When the Four Heavenly Kings have said this, the Four Heavenly Kings hear it and become even more joyful, saying:
'The side of MÄra is diminished, and the side of the true Dharma grows.'
The Four Heavenly Kings then joyfully tell this to Åšakra, King of the Devas, in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three:

'In JambudvÄ«pa, in sequence, up to a certain good man, of such and such a clan, with such and such a name, who has shaved off his beard and hair, put on the Dharma robes, left the household life with right faith, left the noisy places, up to the charnel ground, contemplated the eighteen mental activities according to the Dharma, has already realized that Dharma, and abides in it according to the Dharma.'
When the Four Heavenly Kings had said this to Åšakra, King of the Devas, that KauÅ›ika, Åšakra, King of the Thirty-three Celestials, heard it and was greatly delighted.

Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma - thus, after that bhiká¹£u has contemplated the eighteen mental activities according to the Dharma and attained the first stage, what other different stages will he further realize?
He sees, hears, or knows, or sees with the divine eye:
He further contemplates the four families in sequence. The four are: the family of wisdom, the family of truth, the family of abandonment, and the family of renunciation.
How does a bhiká¹£u abide in the family of wisdom?
It is said:

That bhiká¹£u observes his own body in this way, and thus knows well, in accordance with reality, the various parts of this body: there are the earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and consciousness element.
What is the earth element?
The earth element is of two kinds:
one is internal;
the other is external.
What is internal?
The various parts within the body are called internal, and they are perceived.
What is perceived?
When combined with skin, flesh, etc., it is perceived. Namely, hair, body hair, nails, teeth, etc., are included in the hard and rough, and are perceived as internal.
What else is there?

Namely, hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, blood vessels, bones, marrow, spleen, kidneys, heart, lungs, mucus, saliva, the raw and cooked intestines, the small and large intestines, the stomach, and the head. In the body, all the internal parts that are hard, rough, and perceived are called the internal earth element.
What is called the external earth element?
All external earth, hard and rough, is called the external earth element.
Whether the internal earth element or the external earth element, they are one and the same in being this element.
Contemplating this earth element:
There is no creator, no experiencer, not without causes and conditions, impermanent, not blissful, not a self, and not pure.
A bhiká¹£u who observes in this way attains liberation from the family of wisdom, all of which is not a self, nor does it belong to a self, nor is there a self there.
Thus, knowing and seeing the earth element as it really is, the mind becomes detached.
In this way, a bhiká¹£u attains liberation from the family of wisdom.
What is the water element?
The water element is of two kinds:
first, internal;
second, external.
What is internal?
All that is watery is characterized by the water element, namely, the characteristic of decay;

The moisture in the body, tears, saliva, nasal mucus, brain, blood, fat, marrow, bile, urine, sweat, and so forth - in the body, there are internal water elements that are included in the factors of enlightenment, called the internal water element.
What is called the external water element?

External water elements that are not included in the factors of enlightenment, which are grasped as moisture, are called the external water element.ğŸ”½Because they are not included in the factors of enlightenment, they are called the external water element.
Whether external or internal water elements, they are one unified whole, and this element is simply an element.
Contemplating this water element, it is all not-self, not what belongs to self, and not what has self.
Thus, one accurately and correctly knows and sees the water element, and the mind becomes detached.
Thus, a bhiká¹£u abides in the abode of wisdom.
What is the fire element?
The fire element is of two kinds:
first, internal;
second, external.
What is internal?
Various parts of the body.
If fire is categorized as fire, it is internal and has awareness, namely the warmth of the body that does not burn;
namely, that which can digest.
What is it that can digest?
It refers to consuming food and drink, obtaining the right pleasure from flavors, and digesting them.
In this way, in the body, if the internal and internal parts are categorized as fire, it is internal and has awareness, called the internal fire element.
What is called the external fire element?
All external fire and fire-like things, if warm and categorized as warm, are categorized as non-awareness, because of non-awareness, it is called the external fire element.
If the internal fire element and the external fire element are combined into one, this element is only an element.
Contemplating this fire element, all are not self, not belonging to self, and not what belongs to self.
In this way, correctly knowing the fire element as it truly is, and having seen it as it truly is, the mind becomes detached.
In this way, the fire element has no creator and no experiencer.
What is the wind element?
The wind element is of two kinds:
first, internal;
second, external.
What is internal?
In the body, whatever is internally categorized as wind, or light and moving, categorized as the aspect of awareness.
What are they?
Namely:

upward-moving wind, downward-moving wind, horizontal-moving wind, childbirth-like wind, wind that pricks like needles, wind that cuts like knives, wrongly discriminating wind, swirling wind - such winds move like worms.
Such winds, in eighty ways, move in eighty places;
in this way, internally, in various places, winds are categorized as light and moving, categorized as mature and aware, called the internal wind element.
What is called the external wind element?
External winds, light and moving, uncombined and unaware, are called the external wind element.
Whether the internal wind element or the external wind element, they are one and the same in combination, this element is only an element.
Contemplate this wind element, all of it is not the self, nor is it the possessions of the self, nor is it what belongs to the self.
Thus, this wind element has no creator, and no experiencer.
Thus, thus, having realized it as it truly is, having seen it as it truly is, the mind becomes detached.
Thus, a bhiká¹£u realizes the family of wisdom.
What is called the space element?
The space element also has two kinds:
one is internal;
two is external.
What is internal?

It refers to the internal divisions within this body, the internal divisions of space, the space that is included, the place of awareness, not pervasive, not all-pervading, the place of movement of form, the place where food and drink and various flavors are digested and transformed, the place of expansion;
Moreover, the space in the throat, ears, eyes, nose, the space on the tongue, the space inside the mouth, the space where the tongue moves in the mouth, these are called the internal space element.
What is called the external space element?

The space that is not included in the sense bases, not completely full, not completely pervasive, namely the space between the branches, leaves, and twigs of trees, all the empty spaces in caves, mountain valleys, and ravines, such spaces, external cavities, are called the external space element.
If the space element is included in internal forms, or if the space element is included in external forms, they are combined into one, and this element is only an element.

Contemplating this space element, all are not self, not what belongs to self, nor what is possessed by self. Thus, thus, contemplating the space element, knowing it as it really is, seeing it as it really is, the mind becomes detached.

Having contemplated in this way, one will not be negligent. This realm of space is all not-self, also not what belongs to self, and also not what is possessed by self. There is no doer and no experiencer.
Having known this, the mind becomes detached.
What is the realm of consciousness?
It is said:
The inner and outer combination of the twelve sense bases, eye consciousness sees objects, and mental consciousness discriminates;
In this way, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mental consciousness, in this way the realm of consciousness, the mind is the root, all are known by mental consciousness.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The mind moves in front of the practice of dharmas, the mind has power and is swift.
Having first moved and turned the mind, one is then able to speak and act.
Shaking off all evil karma, one is then able to know rebirth;
Clearly knowing the fruits of karma, one attains the state of immortality.
Being able to control all faculties, delighting in benefiting sentient beings,
This is a peaceful monk.
Riding the carriage of the six faculties, able to slay the enemy of desire,ğŸ”½The brave and wise one practices in the forest, able to reach the place of tranquility.
Content in the forest, lying on the ground with a peaceful mind,
Able to shake off evil dharmas, like the wind scattering heavy clouds.
Good in body and speech, delighting in practicing good conduct,
Seeing the truth and practicing with respect, able to destroy the army of Mara.
Desire and so forth cannot bind, the mind is good and not greedy,
Having much compassion, the monk who practices the path abides.
The sense objects are the cause of bondage, if one does not crave form and so forth,
He will reach the supreme tranquility, reaching the place of no suffering and distress.
Furthermore, the practitioner contemplates in his mind, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma, thinking like this:
The bhiká¹£u observes the eighteen mental activities and accomplishes the first stage, accurately knowing the six elements and attaining the second stage;
further contemplating what dharmas attain the third stage?
He sees, hears, and knows or sees with the divine eye:
accurately knowing the five faculties of sensation, he attains the third stage.
How does he accurately know the desire for the arising of pleasant sensation?

He accurately knows this, and in this way he knows the arising of painful sensation, the arising of joyful sensation, the arising of sorrowful sensation, and the arising of neutral sensation. He knows all that has pleasure, and knows that pleasant sensation arises due to the condition of contact.
Having known pleasant sensation, he accurately knows:
'I know pleasant sensation.'
If that bhiká¹£u knows that pleasant sensation arises due to the condition of contact, he does not give rise to craving and pleasure towards the contact that produces pleasant sensation.
Having known the contact that produces pleasant sensation, then pleasant sensation arises, and then pleasant sensation ceases;
that cessation of pleasant sensation, he accurately knows:
'My pleasant sensation has ceased.'
He thinks like this:
'My painful feelings arise due to causes and conditions.'
He knows that painful feelings arise like pleasant feelings. He knows this as explained, that pleasant feelings arise from contact as a condition, and so on. In this case of painful feelings,
This is explained in detail.
How does a monk know about feelings of joy?
Joyful feelings arise from contact as a condition.
How does a monk know about feelings of sorrow?
Sorrowful feelings arise from contact as a condition.
If one observes in accordance with joyful feelings, joyful feelings will cease;
Seeing their cessation, one becomes free from desire for joyful feelings:
'If my joyful feelings arise and cease at first, seeing their cessation, one knows the feelings as they really are, and the mind becomes free from desire.'
Sorrowful feelings are explained in this way, and so is equanimity.
Knowing this, one attains the third stage.

The earth-dwelling yakshas, having known this, were delighted and passed it up to the sky-dwelling yakshas. The sky-dwelling yakshas heard the Four Heavenly Kings, and those Four Heavenly Kings heard the Four Heavenly Kings, and those Four Heavenly Kings told King Shi Yijun of the KoÅ›ala country:

In JambudvÄ«pa, in such and such a country, in such and such a village, in such and such a town, a good man of such and such a family name and such and such a personal name, having shaved off his beard and hair and donned the Dharma robes, has gone forth with right faith and attained the third ground.
He wishes to do battle with MÄra, to reduce MÄra's faction and increase the friends of the true Dharma.
Having heard this, they became even more delighted.

King Shi Yijun of the KoÅ›ala country then rode on a great elephant named Yinnarabanan, from the first heavenly assembly of great spiritual powers, to the YÄma Heaven and joyfully said:ğŸ”½In JambudvÄ«pa, in order, up to a good man... (explains in detail up to) attaining the third ground.
In JambudvÄ«pa, in sequence, up to a certain good man, speaking extensively up to attaining the third ground.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½
They wish to fight with Mara together, reduce Mara's faction, and expand the friends of the true Dharma.
' The YÄma Heaven gods, having heard this from Åšakra, the king of the gods, became even more delighted.

Moreover, the practitioner contemplates with the mind in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does a bhiká¹£u attain the third ground and subsequently cultivate to attain the fourth ground?
He sees, hears, or knows, or sees with the divine eye:
The bhiká¹£u who wishes to attain the fourth ground observes in this way:
'Due to the condition of contact, I give rise to pleasant feeling;
If the cause of that pleasure, the conditions for pleasure cease, and tranquility is lost, then there is no pleasant feeling.
Due to the condition of contact, I give rise to painful feeling.'
In this way, he abandons painful contact, painful feeling, the origin of suffering, and all the conditions for suffering.
He thus knows that feeling arises from the condition of contact:
'My feeling arises moment by moment together with contact, and arises due to contact.

They do not delight in pleasant feelings, do not delight in pleasant feelings, do not praise those feelings, do not do them more, and do not become attached to them. In this way, painful feelings cannot oppress them, cannot afflict them, cannot disturb them. In this way, they practice equanimity, mindfulness, and right knowledge.
In this way, with regard to these three feelings, the rest of their mind is completely unstained and they let go of everything.
This kind of letting go is pure and bright.
That bhiká¹£u thinks like this:
'My letting go now is like this pure, like this bright. How can I now attain the sphere of infinite space?
' That person thus hopes and wishes to attain the practice of the sphere of infinite space:
'How can I attain the mind of that sphere?
I have already realized letting go, which is ultimately firm and strong.
I now ultimately delight in this letting go, always embracing it without separation. I use this letting go to take up the sphere of infinite space.'

Moreover, I will use this pure and bright equanimity to attain the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception. I aspire to those realms and will practice accordingly.'
That person, practicing in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, thinks like this:
'I now rely on that realm with this equanimity, according to the dharmas of that realm, enabling me to attain them.
I delight in that realm with this equanimity, using it to attain that realm, practicing in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.'
It is like a skilled goldsmith or his disciple who places refined gold in a fire, blows on it with a bellows, holds it with tongs, and polishes it with his hands, refining it well.

That refined gold becomes pliable, pure, bright, and beautiful in color, suitable for any use, and all the ornaments made from it are praiseworthy. Wherever it goes, no one can say anything bad about it;
It is polished without impurities, not mixed, not rough, supremely soft, and all that is made is wonderful, with pure light surpassing other jewels.
However, this skilled craftsman or his disciple, knowing that this true gold can be skillfully refined, knows it is a true treasure;
Having known this, they think of what to make:
'What should be made to bring joy to all who see it?'
Then they make a bell, or use it to adorn the body, either where it is not seen or where it is seen;ğŸ”½If they make earrings to adorn the ears;
If they make a necklace to adorn the neck;
If they use it to make offerings to sutras and treatises;ğŸ”½If they make a ring with a seal pattern to adorn the fingers;
If they make a golden headdress or a topknot crown to adorn the topknot.
Wherever it is used to adorn, it is well-made in that way.
Thus, a wise and well-disciplined bhiká¹£u gives rise to this thought:
'This abandonment of mine is thus pure, thus fresh and bright, thus rightly practiced. Taking the sphere of space, I then correspond.
I rely on this abandonment, fix my thoughts on that place, delight in that place, and use it to take that place.
With this abandonment, I practice the sphere of space, thus the sphere of consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
' Thus he recollects:
'How can this abandonment of mine now be always unmoving, indestructible, and not moment-to-moment ceasing?
' Having contemplated thus, he next also takes the four formless spheres as objects.
That abandonment is neither permanent nor impermanent, neither moving nor unmoving, neither permanent nor impermanent.
He knows thus:

'That sphere of space, thus the sphere of consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, taking those spheres as objects, are neither permanent nor impermanent.
Then, in that place, the mind is not delighted, knowing it is not tranquil, impermanent, and fluctuating.
He further observes feelings, knowing that feelings are about to arise;
Knowing that feelings have arisen, knowing that feelings are about to cease;

Knowing that feelings have ceased, knowing that eye contact arises, in this way, in sequence, knowing that ear contact arises, knowing that nose contact arises, knowing that tongue, body, and mind contact and feelings arise.
Having thus realized feelings, he further deeply observes these feelings:
'Eye contact gives rise to feelings, desire arises, has arisen, and this feeling abides. I know all of this, knowing that my feelings cease, desire ceases, and have ceased.

Moreover, I know that ear contact gives rise to feelings. My eye contact and feelings have ceased, have disappeared, have been abandoned, have been relinquished, and will not come again. When these feelings have ceased, in sequence, I further observe ear contact giving rise to feelings:
Dependent on suffering, dependent on happiness, neither suffering nor happiness.'

The ear contact-born feeling, in this way and that way, accords with observation. Knowing this, one does not give rise to delight in ear-born feeling. Knowing that feeling, one is free from desire and liberated.
Ear contact-born feeling, having thus ceased, observes nose-born feeling, knows nose-born feeling, and the nose contact conditions:
'This feeling of mine arises, born from pleasant conditions, born from painful conditions, born from neither painful nor pleasant conditions.'
In this way and that way, it accords with observation. Nose contact-born feeling, knowing reality as it is, feeling then ceases and disappears, knowing feeling ceases and disappears.
Having thus ceased, it knows nose-born painful feeling, pleasant feeling, and neither painful nor pleasant feeling:
'If later, nose-born feeling arises, observing in this way, it arises like this, having arisen, it again ceases.'
When that has ceased, he observes the sensations arising from the tongue, and later the sensations that arise are also of three kinds, as explained before;
in sequence, up to observing the sensations arising from the mind, which are also of three kinds.
When he thus correctly knows the sensations, he attains the fourth ground and diligently generates effort, wishing to escape the bonds of Mara.

The ground yakshas, knowing this, rejoice, and thus they joyfully tell the sky yakshas, the sky yakshas tell the Four Heavenly Kings like this, the Four Heavenly Kings tell the Four Heavenly Kings like this, and the Four Heavenly Kings tell King Shakra like this.
King Shakra tells the Yamas like this:

'In JambudvÄ«pa, in such and such a country, in such and such a village, in such and such a town, there is a good man of such and such a family name and such and such a given name. He shaves off his beard and hair, dons the Dharma robes, goes forth with right faith, upholds the precepts, and practices diligently. In such and such a sequence, he truly knows and experiences, and attains the fourth stage.
As I have now told the devas, the faction of MÄra is diminished, and the faction of the true Dharma flourishes.'
The YÄma devas see Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, riding his white elephant AirÄvaá¹‡a. Having seen this, the YÄma devas give rise to joy and say to Åšakra, Lord of the Devas:
'Now, Åšakra!
The people of JambudvÄ«pa follow the practice of the Dharma and are able to give rise to love and remembrance. This is what you should do.'

The practitioner further contemplates with internal thought, in accordance with the true Dharma, observing the practice of the Dharma: How does that bhiká¹£u, having abandoned MÄra's bonds, observe the feeling of equanimity?
He sees or knows this through the divine eye:
That bhiká¹£u thus contemplates the feelings with insight, and the feelings born from the conditions of eye-consciousness are unwholesome;
When the second wholesome condition arises, the unwholesome feelings cease, and wholesome feelings are born;
When the conditioned conditions cease, the conditioned feelings cease, and indeterminate feelings arise;
In this way, feelings born from ear-contact, nose-contact, tongue-contact, body-contact, and mind-contact are known, wholesome dharmas are fulfilled, and afflictions become thin.
He cultivates in this way and further contemplates feelings in detail.
He contemplates the feelings of dharmas, and the feelings of dharmas are obstructed together, like how the light of a lamp can be obstructed by sunlight;
In this way, the two feelings are also obstructed in the same way. When wholesome feelings arise, they should be known to obstruct unwholesome feelings.
It is like how the light of a second lamp cannot obstruct the light of the first lamp.
Moreover, he contemplates feelings:
'Which feelings are ultimately mutually obstructive?'
He saw that good feelings are ultimately mutually obstructive with bad feelings, just as the light of a lamp and the light of stars are not mutually obstructive.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u contemplates and observes:
Which feelings and which feelings can destroy which?
He observes in this way that contaminated feelings destroy uncontaminated feelings, just as the light of fire can obstruct the light of snow.
Moreover, which feelings?
Which feelings are superior?
Thus he further contemplates in this way:
Those bad feelings obstruct good feelings, and later arise again.
Just as the light of the sun covers the light of the moon during the day, that light of the moon at night cannot be covered.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u correctly contemplates feelings:
'Many feelings combine, and one feeling can obstruct the superior many feelings.'
He observes that many feelings are worldly feelings;
That one feeling is the supramundane, uncontaminated feeling. This feeling is superior and can obstruct contaminated feelings.
It is like the many stars in the night sky, with the light of the full moon able to obstruct the stars.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u follows along and observes those subtle feelings:
Which are the many feelings?
Namely, those arising from the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body. These are contaminated feelings.
Which are the well-arisen?

He observes that contaminated feelings in the world are many and not uncontaminated. The world is powerless, like the light of the stars in the darkness of night, unable to illuminate well when there is a moon.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u observes those feelings:
'How long does this feeling of mine abide?'
He observes that my feelings abide in the characteristics of arising and ceasing, like a flash of lightning.
Moreover, that bhiká¹£u observes in this way:
What is the meaning of this?
Does the nose feeling arise from the eye feeling?
They correctly contemplate that the objects of the mind-faculty are destroyed by all the objects of the faculties.
Just as the characteristics of cows, horses, camels, donkeys, and buffaloes are different, not a single cause.

In the same way, the objects that arise from the five faculties, since beginningless time, are not a single object of delight and attachment, and the characteristics of the objects are destroyed by the faculties, just as cows, horses, camels, donkeys, and pigs are different.
That bhiká¹£u, contemplating in this way, attains subtle wisdom.
That bhiká¹£u, able to delight in that wisdom and cultivate it much, having contemplated pleasant feelings, follows along to contemplate feelings;
following along to contemplate their end, he thinks like this:
'This feeling of mine arises from the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. Where does it come from when it is born, and where does it go when it ceases?'
That bhiká¹£u follows along to contemplate, seeing the end and cessation of feelings, contemplating the principle;
having contemplated in this way, he knows that eye-feeling has no place it comes from when born, and no place it goes when ceased:
'This eye-consciousness of mine, which did not exist before now exists, and having existed, will again become non-existent.
This eye of mine has no place it comes from, like the water in the ocean;
When it ceases, it goes nowhere, like a river flowing down to the great ocean.

This eye-consciousness of mine, which did not exist before now exists, and having existed, will again become non-existent, it arises from causes and conditions. The same is true for the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.'
It is like a potter or his disciple, who, relying on the wheel, clay, human effort, and water, produces a pot.
This pot does not come from anywhere when it exists, and when it ceases, it goes nowhere. This pot arises from causes and conditions.

In the same way, relying on the eye, form, light, space, and memory, eye-consciousness arises, which is called pleasant, unpleasant, or neither pleasant nor unpleasant, just like that pot. If good causes and conditions produce a good pot, if bad causes and conditions produce a bad pot.
It is just so, if good conditions arise, good eye-consciousness arises, and so do the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind consciousnesses.
If one combines good consciousnesses, one will gradually follow the right path and reach nirvana.

If unwholesome conditions arise, unwholesome eye-consciousness arises, and one gives rise to desire, anger, and delusion, one will fall into the evil destinies of hell, animal realm, and hungry ghost realm in the cycle of birth and death.
